column1: Florida had its first serious "wildland urban interface" fire in 1985 with the Palm Coast Fire
column2: which burned 131 homes. Research on this fire indicated that the most important factor was the proximity of heavy ground vegetation to the structures. Thirteen years later
column3: fires struck the same Palm Coast subdivision. The 1998 fires were national news because the whole county was ordered to evacuate
column5: 000 people were displaced. Fire suppression organizations responded from 44 states
column6: and Florida hosted the largest aerial suppression operation ever conducted in the United States. Because of the massive effort
column8: the citizenry of Palm Coast voted overwhelmingly by a margin of two to one to incorporate as a council/manager form of government. On December 31
column10: the City of Palm Coast was officially incorporated. On October 1
column12: all services were officially transferred from the former Service District to the city of Palm Coast. The five-member City Council is elected at large and serves staggered four-year terms. One member is elected as mayor. The promulgation and adoption of policy are the responsibility of the council
column13: and the execution of such policy is the responsibility of the council-appointed city manager. The city hired its first city manager on April 17

column1: The city provides a wide range of services including development services
column2: fire services
column4: parks and recreational activities. Palm Coast contracts with the Flagler County Sheriff's Office for law enforcement services. As of 2012
column5: the city has plans under way for a new city hall
column8: and additional lands for parks. Preservation and protection of environmentally sensitive lands is a key goal of this city as it prepares for the future.

column1: Palm Coast is located in northeastern Flagler County at 29°32′17″N 81°13′24″W. According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 90.8 square miles (235.3 km2)
column3: of which 89.9 square miles (232.8 km2) is land and 0.97 square miles (2.5 km2)
column5: is water. The city extends north to the Flagler County line
column6: southwest to the Bunnell city limits
column7: and southeast to touch the city of Flagler Beach.

column1: Interstate 95 crosses Palm Coast from north to south
column2: with access from Exit 293 (Matanzas Woods Parkway)
column4: and Exit 284 (Florida State Road 100). U.S. Route 1 runs parallel to I-95 through the western side of Palm Coast

column1: The area around Palm Coast last saw a direct hit from a tropical cyclone in 2004 when Hurricane Charley passed directly over the area. Since 1851 when hurricane tracking data began
column2: 33 hurricanes and tropical storms have directly affected the area.

column5: the people of the city petitioned to have more street lights and sidewalks installed throughout the entire city to reduce the number of pedestrian injuries and deaths.
